tn.ref: Now as they came to Jerusalem ... Bethphage and Bethany, at the Mount of Olives
tn.text: "When Jesus and his disciples came near to Jerusalem, they came to Bethphage and Bethany near the Mount of Olives" (UDB). They have come to Bethphage and Bethany in the vicinity of Jerusalem.
This is the name of a village. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"ahead of us" (UDB)
This refers to a young donkey that is large enough to carry a man.
This can be written in active form. AT: "that no one has ever ridden" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
It can be written clearly what the word "this" refers to. AT: "Why are you untying and taking the colt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"needs it"

tn.ref: will immediately send it back here
tn.text: Jesus will send it back promptly when he is finished using it. AT: "will immediately send it back when he no longer needs it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"The two disciples went"
This refers to a young donkey that is large enough to carry a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mrk:11:01|11:2]].
"They responded"
"as Jesus had told them to respond." This refers to how Jesus had told them to respond to people's questions about taking the colt.
This means that they allowed them to continue doing what they were doing. AT: "let them take the donkey with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: threw their cloaks on it so Jesus could ride it
tn.text: "laid their cloaks on its back so Jesus could ride it." It is easier to ride a colt or a horse when there is a blanket or something similar on its back. In this case, the disciples threw their cloaks on it.
"coats" or "robes"

tn.ref: Many people spread their garments on the road
tn.text: It was a tradition to lay garments on the road in front of important people to honor them. This can be made explicit. AT: "Many people spread their garments on the road to honor him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: others spread branches they had cut from the fields
tn.text: It was a tradition to lay palm branches on the road in front of an important people to honor them. AT: "others spread branches on the road that they had cut from the fields, also to honor him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"who followed him"
This word means "save us" but can also mean "praise God!" Or it may be borrowed into your language. AT: "Praise God" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_transliterate]])
This is referring to Jesus. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Blessed are you, the one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in the name of the Lord
tn.text: This is a metonym for the Lord's authority. AT: "the authority of the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Blessed is the kingdom that is coming." This refers to Jesus coming and ruling as king. AT: "Blessed be the coming of your kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"May God bless" (UDB)
Here David's ancestral line is referred to as himself. AT: "of the line of our father David" or "descended from our father David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "Praise God who is in heaven" or 2) "Let those who are in heaven shout 'Hosanna'."
Here heaven is spoken of as "the highest." AT: "the highest heaven" or "heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"because it was late in the day"

tn.ref: he went out to Bethany with the twelve
tn.text: "he and his twelve disciples left Jerusalem and went to Bethany"
"while they were going back to Jerusalem from Bethany"
This happens while Jesus and his disciples are walking to Jerusalem.

tn.ref: if he could find any fruit on it
tn.text: "if there was any fruit on it"
This means that he did not find any figs. AT: "he found only leaves and no figs on the tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"the time of year"

tn.ref: He spoke to it, "No one will ever eat fruit from you again
tn.text: Jesus speaks to the fig tree and curses it. He speaks to it so that his disciples hear him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
"He spoke to the tree"
The word "it" refers to Jesus speaking to the fig tree.
"Jesus and his disciples came"

tn.ref: began to cast out the sellers and the buyers in the temple
tn.text: Jesus is driving these people out of the temple. This can be written clearly. AT: "began to drive the sellers and buyers out of the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the people who were buying and selling"
God said ahead of time in his word, through the prophet Isaiah, that his temple would be a house of prayer for all the nations.

tn.ref: Is it not written, 'My house will be called ... the nations'?
tn.text: Jesus is rebuking the Jewish leaders for their misuse of the temple. This can be written as a statement. AT: "It is written in the scriptures that God said, 'I want my house to be called a house where people from all nations may pray'" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: But you have made it a den of robbers
tn.text: Jesus compares the people to robbers and the temple to a robbers' den. AT: "But you are like robbers who have made my house into a robbers' den" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"a cave where robbers hide"
"they were seeking a way"
This refers to the time of day when evening begins, that is, when it begins to get dark outside. AT: "whenever it became evening" or "every evening" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Jesus and his disciples left the city"
Jesus uses the example of the fig tree to remind the disciples to have faith in God.
"were walking along the road"

tn.ref: the fig tree withered away to its roots
tn.text: Translate this statement to clarify that the tree died. AT: "the fig tree withered away down to its roots and died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])
"dried up"
It may be helpful to state what Peter remembered. AT: "Peter remembered what Jesus had said to the fig tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])
"Jesus replied to his disciples"
"I tell you the truth." This phrase adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.
"if anyone says"

tn.ref: if he does not doubt in his heart but believes
tn.text: Here "not doubt" is a double negative meaning "truly believe." Jesus says it both ways for emphasis. AT: "if he truly believes in his heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"God will make happen"
"So I tell you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
It is understood that this will happen because God will provide what you ask for. This can be stated clearly. AT: "God will do it for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is common in Hebrew culture to stand when praying to God. AT: "When you pray" (UDB)
"whatever grudge you have against anyone." Here the word "whatever" refers to any grudge you hold against someone for sinning against you or any anger you have against someone.

The next day when Jesus returns to temple, he gives the chief priests, scribes, and elders an answer to their question about his casting the money changers out of the temple area, by asking them another question, which they were not willing to answer.
"Jesus and his disciples came to"

tn.ref: Jesus was walking in the temple
tn.text: This means that Jesus was walking around inside of the temple; he was not walking into the temple.
The word "They" refers to the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders.

tn.ref: By what authority do you do these things? And who gave you the authority to do them?
tn.text: Both of these questions have the same meaning and are asked together to strongly question Jesus' authority. They can be combined. AT: "Who gave you authority to do these things?" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The words "these things" refer to Jesus turning over the sellers' tables in the temple and speaking against what the chief priests and scribes taught. AT: "you to do things like those you did here yesterday" (UDB) (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Answer me"
"The baptism that John performed"

tn.ref: was it from heaven or from men
tn.text: "was it authorized by heaven or by men"
Here "heaven" refers to God. AT: "from God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"from people"
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "If we say 'It was from heaven'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "heaven" refers to God. AT: "From God." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mrk:11:29|11:30]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "him" refers to John the Baptist.
It may be helpful to add the missing information in their answer. AT: "But if we say, 'It was from men'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"From people"

The religious leaders imply that they will suffer from the people if they give this answer. AT: "But if we say, 'From men,' that would not be good." or "But we do not want to say that it was from men." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: They were afraid of the people
tn.text: The author, Mark, explains why the religious leaders did not want to say that John's baptism was from men. This can be stated clearly. "They said this to each other because they were afraid of the people" or "They did not want to say that John's baptism was from men because they were afraid of the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the people all believed"
It may be helpful to add the missing information. AT: "We do not know where the baptism of John came from" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
